lines.text: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Servant!

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Mistress

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Ay, boy, its for love.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Not of you.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Of my mistress, then.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Twere good you knocked him.
Exit

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Servant, you are sad.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: Seem you that you are not

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Haply I do.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: So do counterfeits.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: So do you.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: What seem I that I am not

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Wise.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: What instance of the contrary

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Your folly.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: And how quote you my folly

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: I quote it in your jerkin.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: My jerkin is a doublet.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Well, then, Ill double your folly.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: How

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Give him leave, madam he is a kind of chameleon.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live in your air.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: You have said, sir.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: I know it well, sir you always end ere you begin.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Tis indeed, madam we thank the giver.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Who is that, servant

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Yourself, sweet lady for you gave the fire. Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyships looks, and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall make your wit bankrupt.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: I know it well, sir you have an exchequer of words, and, I think, no other treasure to give your followers, for it appears by their bare liveries, that they live by your bare words.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: No more, gentlemen, no more:here comes my father.
Enter DUKE

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset. Sir Valentine, your fathers in good health: What say you to a letter from your friends Of much good news

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: My lord, I will be thankful. To any happy messenger from thence.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman To be of worth and worthy estimation And not without desert so well reputed.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Hath he not a son

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Ay, my good lord a son that well deserves The honour and regard of such a father.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: You know him well

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: I know him as myself for from our infancy We have conversed and spent our hours together: And though myself have been an idle truant, Omitting the sweet benefit of time To clothe mine age with angellike perfection, Yet hath Sir Proteus, for thats his name, Made use and fair advantage of his days His years but young, but his experience old His head unmellowd, but his judgment ripe And, in a word, for far behind his worth Comes all the praises that I now bestow, He is complete in feature and in mind With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good, He is as worthy for an empress love As meet to be an emperors counsellor. Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me, With commendation from great potentates And here he means to spend his time awhile: I think tis no unwelcome news to you.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Should I have wishd a thing, it had been he.

lines.speaker: duke
lines.text: Welcome him then according to his worth. Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio For Valentine, I need not cite him to it: I will send him hither to you presently.
Exit

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship Had come along with me, but that his mistress Did hold his eyes lockd in her crystal looks.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them Upon some other pawn for fealty.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Nay, then he should be blind and, being blind How could he see his way to seek out you

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself: Upon a homely object Love can wink.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Have done, have done here comes the gentleman.
Exit THURIO
Enter PROTEUS

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you, Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither, If this be he you oft have wishd to hear from.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him To be my fellowservant to your ladyship.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Not so, sweet  lady: but too mean a servant To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Leave off discourse of disability: Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: My duty will I boast of nothing else.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: And duty never yet did want his meed: Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Ill die on him that says so but yourself.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: That you are welcome

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: That you are worthless.
Reenter THURIO

lines.speaker: thurio
lines.text: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

lines.speaker: silvia
lines.text: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio, Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome: Ill leave you to confer of home affairs When you have done, we look to hear from you.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Well both attend upon your ladyship.
Exeunt SILVIA and THURIO

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: And how do yours

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: I left them all in health.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: How does your lady and how thrives your love

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: My tales of love were wont to weary you I know you joy not in a love discourse.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alterd now: I have done penance for contemning Love, Whose high imperious thoughts have punishd me With bitter fasts, with penitential groans, With nightly tears and daily heartsore sighs For in revenge of my contempt of love, Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes And made them watchers of mine own hearts sorrow. O gentle Proteus, Loves a mighty lord, And hath so humbled me, as, I confess, There is no woe to his correction, Nor to his service no such joy on earth. Now no discourse, except it be of love Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep, Upon the very naked name of love.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Enough I read your fortune in your eye. Was this the idol that you worship so

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Even she and is she not a heavenly saint

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: No but she is an earthly paragon.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Call her divine.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: I will not flatter her.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: O, flatter me for love delights in praises.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills, And I must minister the like to you.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Then speak the truth by her if not divine, Yet let her be a principality, Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Except my mistress.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Sweet, except not any Except thou wilt except against my love.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Have I not reason to prefer mine own

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: And I will help thee to prefer her too: She shall be dignified with this high honour To bear my ladys train, lest the base earth Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss And, of so great a favour growing proud, Disdain to root the summerswelling flower And make rough winter everlastingly.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothing To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing She is alone.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Then let her alone.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own, And I as rich in having such a jewel As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl, The water nectar and the rocks pure gold. Forgive me that I do not dream on thee, Because thou seest me dote upon my love. My foolish rival, that her father likes Only for his possessions are so huge, Is gone with her along, and I must after, For love, thou knowst, is full of jealousy.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: But she loves you

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Ay, and we are betrothd: nay, more, our, marriagehour, With all the cunning manner of our flight, Determined of how I must climb her window, The ladder made of cords, and all the means Plotted and greed on for my happiness. Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber, In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: Go on before I shall inquire you forth: I must unto the road, to disembark Some necessaries that I needs must use, And then Ill presently attend you.

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: Will you make haste

lines.speaker: proteus
lines.text: I will. Even as one heat another heat expels, Or as one nail by strength drives out another, So the remembrance of my former love Is by a newer object quite forgotten. Is it mine, or Valentines praise, Her true perfection, or my false transgression, That makes me reasonless to reason thus She is fair and so is Julia that I love That I did love, for now my love is thawd Which, like a waxen image, gainst a fire, Bears no impression of the thing it was. Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold, And that I love him not as I was wont. O, but I love his lady too too much, And thats the reason I love him so little. How shall I dote on her with more advice, That thus without advice begin to love her! Tis but her picture I have yet beheld, And that hath dazzled my reasons light But when I look on her perfections, There is no reason but I shall be blind. If I can cheque my erring love, I will If not, to compass her Ill use my skill.
Exit VALENTINE
Exit
